awd_titl_txt: SDCI NET: Development of an Ultra-high Speed End-to-end Transport Stack based on the Packet Scale Paradigm.
awd_abstract_narration:
End-to-end data transfer rate requirements in the computational science communities
---including computational biology, physics, astronomy, medicine, and environmental
modeling--- are soon to approach the terabit-per-second regime. Unfortunately, the
state-of-the-art in end-to-end transport protocol implementations scales to at most a
few gigabit-per-seconds of single-stream steady-state throughput. This project will
develop a 10Gbps+ Linux transport-layer stack of the novel paradigm of "packet-scale
congestion-control", which can potentially improve scalability by several orders of
magnitude. For this, the project will: (i) develop a non ACK-clocked state machine
that replaces the TCP state machine, and (ii) develop both software-based as well as
hardware-assisted high-speed implementations of precise inter-packet gap control and
packet timestamping. The implementation will be extensively tested on a 10Gbps
in-laboratory test-bed as well as on nationwide NLR paths. The project will then
partner with up to three projects from the scientific domain, for deploying and
evaluating the impact of the protocol stack on their infrastructure. The resultant
implementation is expected to be transformative in the design and implementation of
non ACK-clocked transport protocols. It is expected to dramatically improve large
high-speed bulk data transfers, without requiring expensive dedicated networks, thus
revolutionizing how the computational science community relies on the networking
infrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed, implemented, and evaluated mechanisms to realize the packet-scale paradigm in ultra-high speed network settings. The innovations have been mainly related to: (i) the design of an implementations architecture that can be be deployed in a plug-and-play manner in existing Linux machines, (ii) the design of modules that can create fine-scale inter-packet gaps (and scale well to higher speed networks), (iii) the design of mechanisms to derive robust signatures of end-to-end delay from inter-packet gaps, and (iv) the tunable handling of the tradeoff between responsiveness and stability.

The outcomes of this project are transformative in the following ways:

  • The packet-scale paradigm represents a significant leap in a battered field — the design of high-speed network transport protocols. While most other efforts merely manipulate the protocol response functions, this paradigm questions and sheds the basic operational framework that has been in use for more than two decades. This allows the paradigm to fundamentally change the game on several performance-related elusive issues, including friendly co-existence with conventional low-speed Internet traffic. Our evaluation with prototypes shows that the paradigm holds significant promise to meet the ultra-high speed needs of future terabit networks.
  • The novel operating system modules developed in this project help lay the groundwork for fine-scale control over data transmission. Such a capability (and the Linux modules and API developed in this project) will be significant enablers for developing high-speed versions of protocol designs developed by others, that also rely on bandwidth-probing, packet-pacing, or analysis of packet delays.
  • The encouraging evaluations of our implementation are a gane-changer for DBCC. Borrow from Infocom paper.

In short, we believe that the outcomes of this project are a significant enabler for science domains that rely on distributed computations with large-scale high-speed data transfer needs. We believe that our implementation of the paradigm will scale well as we move to infrastructures with speeds beyond 100 Gbps.

Several communities will benefit from this project:

  • The development of transport protocol implementations that can operate at ultra-high speeds will have a fairly enabling impact on the use of wide-area networks for scientific computation and distributed analysis by the High Energy Physics, Bio-informatics, Radio-astronomy, Medicine, and Genomics communities.
  • The development of an ultra-high speed protocol that can co-exist with conventional Internet transfers, without adversely affecting the performance of the latter, results in enormous cost-saving. Scientific rsearch communities could use existing public networking infrastructure world-wide, without continuing to deploy expensive dedicated networks.
  • Experience in prototyping, experimentation, measurements, and scientific analysis is invaluable to federal, commercail, and academic institutions that are involved in mining for information in large data-sets. Our efforts in developing, deploying and experimentally evaluating our system have been an excellent source of undergraduate and graduate students trained in these aspects.
  • Our efforts in involving minorities in research help broaden the diversity and capabilities of the Computer Science work force.
